awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Conference: Research on Engineering Practice: Catalyzing a Scholarly Community
awd_abstract_narration:
There has arguably never been a more exciting time to be an engineer. In addition to a strong employment outlook for most engineering specialties, engineering careers are constantly being reshaped by rapid technological change, intensified globalization trends, new cross-disciplinary interactions, demographic shifts, and changing organizational structures. In response to these trends, organizations such as ABET, Inc., the National Academy of Engineering (NAE), and the National Science Foundation (NSF) are leading the charge to improve the alignment of engineering education with the ever-changing demands of professional practice. Yet, despite these reforms, not much is known about the diverse and multi-faceted realities of engineering practice and the ways this knowledge can be used to improve the education and training of engineers across career stages. The workshop supported by this award appraises the current state of research on engineering practice, while working to seed and grow an emerging and vibrant scholarly community that is well positioned to carry out evidence-based transformations of engineering education programs in both academic and industry settings. Participants will include researchers, educators, policymakers, and employers invested in using theory and research on engineering practice to reimagine and transform engineering education and the workforce.

A two-day workshop will bring together a diverse group of approximately 25-30 participants to collaboratively discuss and investigate research on engineering practice. The workshop will be convened immediately prior to, and co-located with, the Frontiers in Education (FIE) Annual Conference in October 2018. Presentations, panels, networking sessions, and group discussions will be used to collectively develop a deeper understanding of engineering practice. Participants will then apply that understanding in interactive sessions focused on using research on engineering practice to transform engineering education and the workforce. The workshop has four main goals. First, a new, global agenda will be defined to inform key stakeholders in decisions about future research on engineering practice. Second, the participants and facilitators will co-create a compendium of literature, topics, sites, partners, methods, and theories that participants and other researchers can draw upon for their own work. Third, the workshop represents a unique opportunity to engage partners from education, policy, and industry in conversation about how research on engineering practice can be used to bring engineering education and professional engineering work into closer alignment. Finally, the workshop will catalyze new research collaborations, projects, and funding proposals related to engineering practice. Workshop activities will incorporate discussions of missing voices and contexts in the literature to identify critical areas for future research that supports broadening participation. Anticipated outcomes include an editorial or position piece on the current state of research on engineering education and actionable guidelines for future research, an edited volume or special issue of a journal comprised of papers or commentaries on engineering education and practice, and a workshop summary report. A special session during the 2018 FIE conference is also planned, to share highlights from the workshop, provide preliminary guidance on methods and approaches for research on engineering practice, and further grow the community of interest among a larger number of potential participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this collaborative conference proposal was to increase and enhance the engineering education field's understanding of engineering practice through research. Engineering is in a strong position to contribute to the welfare of society and the development of individual careers. Industry, government, and professional societies have made strides toward supporting the opportunities afforded by and to engineers, focusing particularly on the better alignment of engineering education and engineering practice. Yet, while engineering education has made great strides to prepare students, it has not kept pace with the varied and rapidly changing engineering landscape, meaning that alignment with engineering practice is not as strong as it could be. An opportunity simultaneously exists to reimagine what future engineering practice could look like for engineering organizations, engineers, and society.

To that end, the grant team developed and delivered a two-day pre-conference Research on Engineering Practice (REP) workshop and follow-up session at the 2018 Frontiers in Education (FIE) Annual Conference, to co-create an understanding of engineering practice and critical research needs (https://www.inesweb.org/rep2018). The workshop convened a selected group of engineering educators and practitioners working to advance research on engineering practice, including how engineers are educated at school and in workplaces. Workshop participants critically reflected on the framing and study of engineering practice and explored opportunities for collaboration. The follow-up special session enabled educators and researchers to explore how the community could leverage research on engineering practice to reimagine engineering education or work.

Towards this end, the project activities achieved the following goals: (1) Draw on existing and emerging bodies of research to develop a deeper, more comprehensive understanding of engineering practice and its potential impacts for a variety of partners, including industry, academia, engineers, students, and the public; (2) Foster a diverse and scholarly community centered on research on engineering practice, with a specific focus on growing the number of early-career scholars involved (i.e., graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and early career faculty and research scientists); (3) Identify actionable guidance for future research on engineering practice that captures critical topics, questions, and research infrastructure needs; (4) Seed new research collaborations and funding proposals on engineering practice and evidence-based transformations of engineering education and practice in both academic and industry settings.

Intellectual Merit: This project provided opportunities for participants to further the definition of engineering practice and the bounds of engineering practice research in three key ways. First, the project advances calls for more scholarship on engineering practice through the development of a research agenda to guide future work. The agenda identifies four research areas of opportunity for the field: (a) deeper investigations into the definition of engineering practice; (b) study of several themes related to engineering practice identified by workshop participants as key; (c) development of new methods and infrastructure to support research on engineering practice; and (d) new thinking about ways of enabling translational research on engineering practice. Second, the development of a community of researchers, employers, and educators served as an important opportunity for exploring how research findings on engineering practice can be used to bring engineering education and professional engineering work in closer alignment. The workshop and other activities established a clearer group identity for the community of scholar-practitioners who specifically focus on the connections between engineering education and engineering practice. Finally, the project catalyzed new research collaborations, including a funded NSF grant project, conference proceedings and presentations. Further dissemination of the results occurred through a 2021 special issue of the journal, Engineering Studies, featuring four articles describing studies of early-career engineering practice and an editorial by the four members of the grant team.

Broader Impact: The REP workshop and related activities provided a unique opportunity to encourage interaction between academia and industry through the joint development of recommendations to improve engineering education and the workplace. The workshop enabled the establishment of a vibrant community of scholar-practitioners dedicated to supporting student success in the workplace. Additionally, an emphasis of the project's community building was on creating opportunities for socialization of early-career scholars into the community and providing infrastructure for their successful engagement in this research area. Lastly, workshop activities were designed explicitly to include discussions of missing voices and contexts in the literature to identify critical areas for future research that supports broadening participation. The resulting research agenda for this project, along with our published editorial in the journal Engineering Studies, will elevate these critical areas for future work in the minds of academics, researchers, industry members, government agencies, and the professional societies. Together, the dual emphases of this project on community building and translating research into impact have the potential to influence engineering education and practice at a variety of levels and to support the NSF's goals of achieving broader impacts with our work.
